<Assistant>LLM (Large Language Models) are text-based AI that have brought significant advancements in machine learning.
Many LLMs are specialized in generating the continuation of text as generative AI, but with some ingenuity, they can also be used as chat-style interfaces.  
The most common mechanism behind LLMs is based on probabilistic models.  
LLMs break down text into small parts using a mechanism called a "tokenizer" and learn the frequency and patterns of each word or phrase.
These patterns and frequencies are expressed probabilistically, with words having a higher probability being more likely to be generated. However, words with lower probabilities may still be generated under certain conditions. 
Low-probability words can sometimes lead to unnatural contexts or errors, which is one of the weaknesses of LLMs.  
However, as the size of LLMs increases, the probability of generating correct words in accordance with the usual context also increases, making it easier to generate fewer errors in text. 
Therefore, by choosing the largest model possible, it is possible to generate highly accurate text even in local environments.
Next, let's explain LLM models.  
An LLM model refers to the compilation of large LLM data into an executable format. A commonly used tool is the Python library "Transformers." By using this library, you can combine datasets and tokenizers to build generative AI.
In summary:
- LLMs are the foundation for building models that handle language, including generative AI, and the term can also refer to the model itself.
- Generative AI predicts the next word probabilistically using LLMs to generate text.
- By using the Transformers library in Python, you can easily create generative AI.</Assistant>
